results.title: Gatick (preview for an interactive work)
results.creator_credit: Melanie Simpson and Advanced Diploma of Multimedia (ADoM), Swinburne University of Technology (formerly Electronic Design and Interactive Media (EDIM)
results.brief_description: As part of the end of year screening for the Swinburne, EDIM (Electronic Design and Interactive Media) course - those students who had completed interactive coursework were required to create a linear representation of their work for the showreel. This student should be contacted and asked to submit the full work to the Interactive collection

results.title: M'eza (preview for an interactive installation)
results.creator_credit: Anita Bacic and Advanced Diploma of Multimedia (ADoM), Swinburne University of Technology (formerly Electronic Design and Interactive Media (EDIM)
results.brief_description: As part of the end of year screening for the Swinburne, EDIM (Electronic Design and Interactive Media) course - those students who had completed interactive coursework were required to create a linear representation of their work for the showreel. M’eza is an immersive art-piece screened at Videobrasil Electronic Art festival 2003. Artist should be contacted at a later date for a further explanation of the work

results.title: Marks and sparks
results.brief_description: Marks and Sparks will explore the minute, often subtle, fashion and bodily adornments of cultural resistance. From badges and t-shirts to jewellery, tattoos and haircuts, this will be a clever and often light examination of cultural markings disassociated from the faces and bodies that they adorn. Filmed in and around the streets of Melbourne, each marking will be distinguished by its intention to create a spark of jolt or resistance when worn on the street.

results.title: Sharpies [a gathering]
results.brief_description: Greg Mcainsh’s 1974 film ‘Sharpies’ documented a massive gathering of the Melbourne Sharpies at a Lobby Loyde concert. The final black and white short film is an exemplary cultural document of a time, a place and a powerful gathering of cultural resistance. This work uses the original footage and materials to present a silent exploration of the Sharpies at this particular moment in Melbourne’s history.

results.title: Tag
results.brief_description: This proposed public imaging project shows a middle-aged woman standing in the middle of a well-furnished lounge room, wearing only her underwear and a blindfold. Other middle-aged people stand around her, also in their underwear, as she tries to find them while blindfolded. Bumping into things, tripping over furniture and laughing in the process- we follow the game from room to room as the woman in the blindfold tries to catch the various people taunting her. Finally tagging a younger man in the kitchen, the woman rips off the blindfold to see who she has caught. The image then cuts to static briefly and we start the game again, only this time with the man that was found or “tagged” now wearing the blindfold. This process repeats a number of times until most people at the party have been blindfolded. Stylistically, the video material will be a mixture of handheld home video cinematography juxtaposed with locked-off tripod material shot with multiple video cameras. The video imagery will then be degraded and transferred to 16mm- the final, highly textured imagery resembling a badly tuned television broadcast of surveillance camera footage.

results.title: Sharpies [a documented history]
results.brief_description: Using Larry Jenkins’ extraordinary and comprehensive photographic archives of the Sharpies throughout the 1970s, this Public Imaging work is an edited collage of photographic materials and provides viewers with a rare insight into this counter cultural grouping. Faces, places, gatherings, gestures and fashion are explored through this rhythmic assemblage of images. The work consists of two sections: one consisting primarily of portraits and social groupings; the second concentrating on details of gestures and adornments representative of Sharpie culture.
